$1,250,000 cash with no strings attached.
It was, of
course,
in view of the State Department's stand,
the one course left
open to us.
Bond made a wonderful deal under all the cir-
cumstances and PAA got the money on December 30th.
At Hongkong the British refused to recognize the sale
even
though it was made by the then British-recognized gov-
ernment of China and
covered property which was legally
theirs
to dispose of as they wished.
The whole question of title to
the aircraft is now before the Hongkong court.
Meanwhile, the
British have recognized the Communist government.
The airport
is covered with airplanes and the only flying is being done by
swarms of buzzard-like lawyers waiting to swoop down on any
claim which appears vulnerable.
I stayed in Hongkong only two days and then came up
here after making arrangements for Debby and Hebe to
get hotel
space from February 10th to l6th in the Colony.
We felt they
should leave Bangkok before the big meeting of diplomats which
will be held there starting February 13th as hotel accommodations
in Bangkok are both scarce and substandard.
Having spent a few days in India enroute here I feel
as well qualified as most experts to discuss the India-Pakistan
cron the pond top.
You know what was formerly India, a piece of pie-
shaped land, is now divided very roughly by a wide strip down
from the broad top to either side of the point, and that section
is called India.
It takes in Calcutta
on the east and Bombay
on
west but does not include Karschi which is the capital
The small
sections on either side of this wide
strip are called East Pakistan and West Pakistan.
of the latter country are Moslems while the Indians are Hindus.
Such is the hatred of the one for the other that there can be
no peace between them.
Both claimed the erstwhile independent
Hyderabad,
the ruler of which was Moslem but the big majority
of the people were Hindus; Pandit Nehru took Hyderabed by force
of arms but he contends with respect to the only large inde-
pendent state left (i.e. Kashnir)
that India must heve that,
too although the situation in Kashmir is exectly the reverse
of Hyderabad only in this instance the ruler of Kashmir is a
Hindu and the people are probably 80% Moslem.
Apparently
among politicians - no matter how elevated their speeches -
consistency is not & virtue.
The pity of the whole thing is that both countries
are spending the largest part of their national income on war
material and military establishments.
Another tragic con-
sequence is that Pakistan is more than self-sufficient on food-
stuff while thousands of Indiens are starving.
Nevertheless,
Pakistan is exporting wheat to Europe while its neighbor
India is importing wheat from Australia.
Furthermore, Pakistan
has large dollar receipts from the sale of long staple cotton,
hides, jute and minerals while India must import many
of these products in order to run its industrial
plants,
Pakistan won't sell to them.
India has a population of about
